page.title: 02Geography and Ecology
page.content: The country around Woodcote is relatively high {606 ft at the water tower},sloping away on three sides down to the curve of the Thames,and giving fine open views North and West to green country and the downland beyond.The soil is chalk with clay pockets ,well drained,with no rivers but some ponds.Much of the area is still covered by beautiful woodland, mainly beech with a little oak and birch and one or two coniferous plantations.There are several small farms of mixed arable and pasture. Woodcote itself has grown rapidly over the last 20 years,and is now a rather straggling development.One loss to the ecology has been most of Woodcote Common,which once grew wild to the top of Greenmoor Hill; now all that remains is a village green edged by allotments.
